bibl.title: Letter from Thurman B. Rice to Philip Showalter Hench, February 17, 1948

div1.p: Rice discusses Reed's presentation at the Indianapolis medical conference, in 1900. Rice notes that Reed's paper was little talked about by the conference participants. Rice agrees to provide Hench with a copy of his biography of Hurty.

div1.head: Letter from Thurman B. Rice to Philip Showalter Hench, February 17, 1948
div1.opener:
INDIANA UNIVERSITY MEDICAL CENTER
1040-1232 WEST MICHIGAN STREET
INDIANAPOLIS 7, INDIANA
February 17, 1948
DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH
Philip S. Hench, M. D.
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Your letter of February 10 gave me a great deal of pleasure. I would have
answered it sooner had I not been out of the City at the time it arrived.
Your use of this book is exactly what I would wish for it, and is the real
reason why it was written.

Enclosed you will find some cards which are copies of the material to be
found in the local newspapers as of the date just before and just after
the coming of Walter Reed to Indianapolis on October 23, 1900. There is
nothing at all about him before that date for the very simple reason that
his name was not on the regular program, but was put on at an urgent request
from him and the Army, as I understand it. Then there is almost nothing
about the paper and no repercussions for some time after for the very simple
reason that the people who were here did not really appreciate the signifi-
cance of the paper. Perhaps that was asking too much of them. Evidently
from what one of the papers said it was an interesting paper and may have
been given a little attention simply as a shot in the dark. You will notice
that one of the papers says that they received it with much interest and ex-
tended the time alloted to him.

Concerning the surmise that he may have stayed at the Claypool Hotel, I believe
I am certain that the Claypool Hotel was not in existence at that time. The
site of the Claypool is on that of the old Bates House. I know that the Bates
House was there at that time because a delegate to the convention died at the
Bates House during the meeting of the Association. I believe the first date
for the Claypool is about 1904. I would be strongly inclined to think that
there is no hotel in Indianapolis now that would have records of the 1904
registry. In the first place, the principal hotels have been built quite a
bit since that time. The Dennison Hotel was in existence then and was very
prominent but it has long been destroyed and I feel sure the records are lost.
There is something in the paper which led my secretary and me to believe that
Dr. Reed was in the city the night before he read his paper, but where he stayed
I have no idea and am very much afraid it could not be found except perhaps by
prodigious effort.

Any photographs that we have used you will be welcome to. I rather doubt if I
have where I can put my finger on it, the original of the photograph showing
the room where he read his paper. We do have however, the cuts from which the
Dr. Hench
Page Two
Feb. 17, 1948
pictures were made as shown in the book about Dr. Hurty. We will be glad to
lend you these cuts along with the pictures showing the outer appearance of
the old German House where the paper was read. Anything of this sort that
you would like to have we are delighted to offer.

I am sure you have all the data you need about Kissinger and I doubt if you
would be interested in the other yellow fever martyrs that have been connected
with the State of Indiana. It is rather surprising that Indiana should have
played so important a role in yellow fever considering the fact that so far
as I know there was never a case this far north, though it was in southern
Indiana.

If I can be of any further help to you I assure you I shall be delighted.
Incidentally, we did find in the newspaper the names of the persons who were
taken in as members at this meeting. By and large I suppose they would average
younger than most of the men at the meeting, yet I feel sure that nearly all of
them are dead. If a man were thirty years of age -- and he rarely attends a
national meeting under that age -- it would make him now 78 years of age. It is
very doubtful if anyone hearing that paper at that time would attach enough
significance to it to have remembered it with any degree of accuracy. We copied
the names of the persons taken into the organization in 1900, and almost all of
the men I know are now certainly dead. There is one possibility; I believe that
I am right in thinking that Dr. A. W. Bitting is alive, or at least was alive, a
few years back. He would be an extremely old man however. He was a veterinarian
rather than an M.D., and probably would not attach great significance to Reed's
paper. Dr. Bitting was at that time connected with Purdue University and was one
of the very first men in the United States to do tuberculin testing of cattle,
and he also called attention to the fact that the milk of cows which had suffered
from contagious abortion was not fit for human consumption. This was a very for-
ward view to be taken about 1898. Dr. Bitting, when last I heard from him, was
still alive and living somewhere in the west. I have an idea that the American
Veterinary Association could tell you how to find him or to tell you if he is
still alive. I would think however, that his chance of remembering Reed's paper
would be very slight.

I think I can furnish you with copies of the Bulletin of the Indiana State Board
of Health which carry the story of Chapters 28 and 29 of the Hurty Biography, or
if you would wish me to send you a copy of the Hurty Biography I can do so under
the following circumstances: This book is not arranged for sale; it can be given
away or it can be traded for a contribution to a fund which is being used to have
an oil painting of Dr. Hurty made to hang in the auditorium of the new State Board
of Health building. If you will be willing to make a contribution of five or ten
dollars, I will then make you a contribution of the book with the understanding
that when you are through with it personally I would like for you to give it to
some library where it could be a matter of standard reference. Please bear in
mind that we will be glad to send you a Bulletin containing those two chapters in
which you are most interested withat no cost whatever.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, Thurman B. Rice, M. D.
